turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Veldman, you may resume whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.
At the time of the luncheon recess, I was attempting to answer a question by one of the Members of the Court.

Mr. Justice Dooley, at page A7 of his opinion as it appears in the petition for certiorari seems to be defining lesser included offense under the concept of double jeopardy, and I submit to you that one of his errors is that he misdefines it.
He speaks in terms of what the fact of the lesser offense must usually contain and no element not found in the greater.

And I would submit to this Honorable Court that it is abundantly clear from the cases such as Brown v. Ohio, such as, for example, Virgin Islands v. Acquino in the intermediate appellate court, that for double jeopardy purposes the lesser included offense situation is thusly defined.
The greater offense will always and of necessity include all of the elements of the lesser.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Could you cite where on page A7 he says that it is usually included?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: He says -- if Your Honor will bear with me for just a moment.
On page A7, three lines from the bottom, a new paragraph begins.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, it says, "As is usually the situation between greater and lesser included offenses."

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: "... the lesser offense, failing to reduce..." -- but, you see, he says, Your Honor, it is usually the situation, and I think, unless I misinterpret his language, I believe that that indicates that he has misapprehended the rule, the rule of the definition there.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, he says, in any event, in this case the lesser offense requires no proof beyond that which is necessary for a conviction of the greater.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Which, of course, I submit to this Court is totally not true.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Certainly the corollary is not true, that the manslaughter charge requires proof of the homicide, whereas the lesser included offense doesn't to have a homicide or even an accident.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Yes, the so-called lesser included offense involves no element of death, it doesn't even necessarily involve an element of collision with any person.

The so-called greater offense, on the other hand, can be easily proven in a number of instances without proving the lesser, since voluntary manslaughter, as Your Honors can see defined statutorily, and I have set it out at page 16 of our principal brief, clearly you can commit involuntary manslaughter in Illinois easily without the use of an automobile and therefore under no stretch of the imagination.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: I have two problems with your argument and I would like you to perhaps comment on it.

First of all, in the statute which is set out at page A6 in the petition, there is an "(a)" on the manslaughter and there is a "(b)" that says, "If the acts which cause the death consist of the driving of a motor vehicle," and then it goes on, which is I take it a sub-category of the voluntary manslaughter.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: It is --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Which is, of course, the sub-category we have here.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: It is the offense which is known in Illinois as reckless homicide.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Right.
Which is, I gather, a lesser included offense within--

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: It is characterized in the statute, if you will notice, as an included offense.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Now, would you say that the reckless driving of a vehicle is a lesser included offense within the offense of reckless homicide?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Would I say that --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: In other words, what I am suggesting is a sort of a pyramid, the broadest category is the involuntary manslaughter, included within that category is the species reckless homicide and an even lesser within that category is the reckless driving of the vehicle.
Each is lesser of the next step up.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Well, perhaps if we had the reckless driving of the vehicle, you might have an instance where it might be an included offense, but what I think you cannot -- even in Your Honor's pyramid of setting up sub-categories, you cannot make failing to reduce speed a lesser included offense even a reckless homicide because all that you are talking about in failure to reduce speed is a simple violation of due care by not reducing speed even to avoid, say, an empty wagon which on the highway.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: But the statutory definition of failure to reduce speed is not limited to cases of failure to reduce speed but also include driving at a speed that is greater than reasonable and proper and so forth.
There are a lot of --

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Well, I think a great many things, as Your Honor can see at page 17 in the people's principal brief, there are a great many things which are included within this particular section of the Illinois Vehicle Code.
And I think there are a number of separate and distinct offenses which might be committed under this section.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Right.

The question is, I suppose -- let me put it a little differently -- the indictment for manslaughter that is quoted on page 4 of the appendix alleges that John M. Vitale has on or about so-and-so committed the offense of involuntary manslaughter.
In that, he without lawful justification, while recklessly driving a motor vehicle, caused the death of George Kech.
Could they prove that charge without also proving a violation of failing to reduce speed?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: I don't think that is clear as the case in the posture in which this case comes before this Court.
There was a police report which indicated that Vitale had violate a number of Illinois traffic laws.

We don't -- I don't think that at this juncture, as the case presently comes before the Court, that we can say -- and I certainly personally cannot say -- whether the proof of the involuntary manslaughter would have involved the failure to reduce speed necessarily or not.
I think that had the case not been --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Wouldn't it necessarily have proved that he was driving recklessly and without proper regard to traffic conditions and the use of the highway in a way that endangered the safety of any person or property?
Wouldn't it necessarily prove that he endangered the safety of the person he killed?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Oh, it would --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That is what the statute calls -- that is the statutory definition of --

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: But do you notice, Your Honor, that the statute -- the statute begins -- we are talking about traffic statute --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: The statute begins, "No vehicle may be driven upon a highway of this state at a speed which is greater than reasonable," et cetera, and it goes on and it makes a number of what I would consider to be possibly separate and distinct traffic offenses, one of which is failure to reduce speed.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: And I think Mr. Justice Underwood commented in his dissenting opinion on this very subject, that it was impossible to know which of the number of possible violations committed under this or other sections might have been the basic proof in the involuntary manslaughter.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Was all of this argued before the lower court, the fact that this was not double jeopardy and the fact that under Illinois law this was not -- was all of this argued?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: No, actually, Your Honor, it wasn't.
The --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, you had an opportunity to argue it, didn't you?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: The way the case came, if Your Honor will note appendix B of the petition for certiorari, the way that the cause came to the Supreme Court of Illinois, the Appellate Court of Illinois for the First District had decided that they had not said much or anything about the double jeopardy question involved in the case.
They had simply based it on an Illinois statute.
Mr. Justice Dooley and the majority of the Illinois Supreme Court in their opinion said we find an even more compelling rationale in the Fifth Amendment of the United States Constitution.
This forum, the forum before this Honorable Court is really the first time in which a full-fledged argument on the double jeopardy aspects of this case has been made, as I see it.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is this the first time there was an opportunity to argue it?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: No, and I believe the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You are not saying that you didn't have an opportunity, are you?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Well, I don't think that -- I'm sorry, I don't think I follow Your Honor's question.
I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: All you are entitled to is an opportunity to present your argument, that is all you have a right to?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You don't have a right to ask somebody else to do your arguing for you?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: No, you do not, Your Honor, but the point is I think that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I shouldn't think the State of Illinois would need any help.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Did you make all these arguments to the Illinois Supreme Court?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: No, we did not because --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Were you arguing just the state law question?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Basically the people's brief which is in the Supreme Court of Illinois, which I might point I did not either write or argue -- dealt basically with the state law question which came up from the Appellate Court.

We have the procedure in Illinois of leave to appeal, and one's petition for leave to appeal is normally limited to those questions in the Appellate Court which are considered error by the petitioner.
So we were somewhat limited in what we could argue before the Supreme Court of Illinois.

And the briefs for respondent in the Supreme Court of Illinois really did not bring out the double jeopardy question which under Illinois court procedure, again, limited the people in that we were compelled basically to keep our answer within the bounds raised by the party appellee there.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You say that the Illinois Appellate Court relied on the Illinois statute barring prosecutions analogous to double jeopardy?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: The so-called compulsory joinder statute in Illinois.

The Appellate Court opinion I think can be pretty much condensed down to the fact that this prosecution violated sections 3-3 and 3-4 of chapter 38 of the Illinois Revised Statutes in that all of these offenses could have and should have been joined before a single court for trial.
The Supreme Court of Illinois totally departed from that rationale.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Has there ever been an adjudication on the merits of either of these two charges?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Of these two charges, an adjudication on the merits?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Yes.
There has been an adjudication of the merits, although we don't have a transcript so we don't know what took place.
But Mr. Vitale has been found guilty and he did not plead guilty.
He was found guilty in the traffic proceeding and was fined in the sum of $15.
And I can only assume that there was there some sort of trial and adjudication, although we do not have a transcript before us.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Veldman, it occurs to me that as a matter of Illinois law, we do have an opinion of the intermediate, the Appellate Court to the effect that these two offenses are the same offense within the meaning of the Illinois Criminal Code.
That holding was not reviewed by the Illinois Supreme Court which apparently went on federal grounds.
But the highest court of the state which has spoken to the issue has told us that as a matter of Illinois law we have the same offense, isn't that true?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: The highest court that has spoken on the issue, yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And aren't we bound by the teaching of the highest court of Illinois that tells us anything about a state law issue?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: You do not have a final determination of that issue by the highest reviewing court.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But it is unreversed at least.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Yes, it is unreversed in the sense that it is untouched.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: In other words, the Illinois Supreme Court may have merely said yes and, oh, by the way, it also violates the federal Constitution.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: No, but they did not say that, Your Honor.

They specifically, in answer to our petition for certiorari 78-2, when this Honorable Court sent the case back, the Supreme Court of Illinois specified that its opinion was based on the Firth Amendment, so they declined to decide the issue, and I can understand that because the committee comments appended to section 3-3 and 3-4 -- and those committee comments in Illinois are proper source of legislative intent -- indicate that what those sections were basically meant to cover was an instance involving multiple prosecutions under a single act or a series of acts which were not covered or barred by the concept of double jeopardy in the Fifth Amendment, and it may have very well been that finding, as they did, that the Fifth Amendment barred the prosecution, that the Supreme Court of Illinois thought it superfluous to discuss the Illinois statute under those conditions.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Suppose, Mr. Veldman, hypothetically -- this is a further hypothetical -- you could persuade us that there was some basis for reversing the Supreme Court of Illinois on their federal holding, would there be anything to prevent that court when the case was remanded from in effect adopting the Court of Appeals opinion and putting it on state grounds and therefore impervious to any challenge?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: I think that having determined that in the basis of its opinion was purely federal constitutional grounds, that the Supreme Court of Illinois would be precluded from so doing.
I should think that --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How could anyone preclude them from saying, as Mr. Justice Stevens just suggested, the inverse of what you suggested, as a matter of fact, that if the is the attitude of the Supreme Court of the United States, all right, we will decide it on state grounds and then decide it just the way the Court of Appeals did.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Well, I suppose that in theory there is nothing to prevent them from doing it, but I think that in actuality the proper remedy -- and I think that if I were before the Supreme Court of Illinois, I would argue that the proper remedy, having decided it on federal constitutional grounds and been then reversed, would be to return the case to the Unified Circuit Court of Cook County for further proceedings under this indictment, and the question there, I think we would then have perhaps the question of the applicability of the statute but I think it would be raised properly in the trial court.

I think it would ill-behoove the Supreme Court of Illinois to say, well, we decided our opinion was on one rationale but since they won't buy that we will just go 180 degrees the other way, and I cannot conceive, being somewhat familiar with the Justices on the Supreme Court of Illinois, that they would do that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: They wouldn't be going the other way, they would just be reaching the same result.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Well, they would be reaching the same result but they would be reaching the same result on a completely different rationale.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That is all right but they would be going on state grounds whereas now they have decided it on federal.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: But they have said, Your Honor, in answer --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: At least if we disagreed with them, we would have told them that they were wrong on the federal ground and leave it to them to decide it on state grounds.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Yes, if nothing else.

And as I have said, their specific answer to the inquiry of this Court under the petition for certiorari, the original petition for certiorari in this case was, the question presented to the Supreme Court of Illinois was have you decided this case on state grounds, federal grounds or both, and the answer was federal grounds alone.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But that doesn't prevent them, if we tell them they were wrong on federal grounds, when it goes back to them, saying, all right, we were wrong on the federal grounds, we will now address the state grounds.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Yes, I suppose they could do that.
They could --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You certainly took the state grounds to them, didn't you? You must have.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Yes, we did.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That is about the only ground you took to them.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: And they ignored it.
They in fact ignored it.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Veldman, is that really quite correct?

At page A3 of the petition, after reviewing the proceeding in the Appellate Court, they conclude that that court had concluded that the Appellate Court concluded that the acts in both the offense of failure to reduce speed and the offense of involuntary manslaughter were identical with the exception in the manslaughter offense a death was involved.
Then they said it follows from that that under the Illinois statute 3(b), since the prosecutor knew about both at the same time, as a matter of state law dismissal was required.
Then they said after that there is an even more compelling reason for dismissal giving this hypothesis, that is that the double jeopardy clause of the Federal Constitution also requires dismissal.
Now, what is the federal error in that analysis?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: The federal error in the analysis of the state statute?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What federal error did the Illinois Supreme Court commit, given the identity of the offenses which the Appellate Court had found and which the Supreme Court of Illinois did not disagree with but merely said we need not rely on the state statute that requires dismissal when identical offenses are involved, we can rely on the federal Constitution that requires dismissal when identical offenses are involved.
What is the federal error that that court committed?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: I think the error which was committed by that court was first in its interpretation of the double jeopardy clause, and secondly in finding that under Illinois law those offenses are the same offense.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, the latter theory is a state law question.
What was its erroneous interpretation of the double jeopardy clause?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: But I don't think -- let me put it this way.
I don't think -- I see my time is expired, but I would like to answer Your Honor's question if I may.
I don't think that you can quite divorce the two things in the way that Mr. Justice Dooley wrote his opinion.
He seems to interpret the Illinois statutes but on federal constitutional grounds, and I think that one cannot divorce the two things.
And I think the federal --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What do you mean by that?
How can you --

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: For example, he defines --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- err on state statutory law on federal constitutional grounds?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: He says --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: If as a matter of state law first degree murder includes manslaughter, say, how is that affected one way or the other by the federal Constitution?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Because unless I misread the position taken by Mr. Justice Dooley and the majority of the Supreme Court of Illinois, their position was that the offenses were the same offense for double jeopardy purposes but then the statute barred them.
It would have barred them in Illinois too had they --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, he is saying it is a lesser included offense that is a matter of Illinois law.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Therefore under Brown v. Ohio we know that they are the same offence for the meeting in the constitution.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: For the Blockbuger test.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The Blockburger original test was not a double jeopardy case.
It was just a matter of statutory construction.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: But what I am saying here is that I think that as you not believe that this court can be bound by what is a total erroneous interpretation of what is a lesser included offense because if this court is so bound then in fact the Illinois supreme court by determining an Illinois question would be detecting the applicapabilty of Brown v. Ohio in this court --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And so -- legislature.
And so could the legislature of any state, that's one of the results of Briton against Maryland.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Is that state legislator?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: The state legislators can define offences as lesser included offences.

I would say up to a point, may I say that, may I just say this I think one reaches a point and please bear with me I hope my thinking is clear one reaches at point where the lesser included offences doctrine can be so extended as to violate for example due process because one could have a conviction upon a charge never made against the criminal defendant if in fact lesser included offences given to broad and interpretation.
And I don't think that this Court --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What would be an example of that?

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: An example of that --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Are you responding to the question now or are you continuing your --

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: I was attempting to respond.
I realize my time is run, Your Honor.
Do you wish me to conclude?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Respond to the question.
Respond to the question, please.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: Thank you.
All right.
An example of that might -- I am trying to think very quickly of one example --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I just wondered what sort of thing you had in mind, that's all.

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: For example, one could have -- one could be convicted of murder.
Take an extreme example.

Suppose someone were charged with murder and then were convicted of armed robbery on the evidence presented and the legislature said, well, armed robbery may be a lesser included offense of murder, and this Court -- now, that is reduxio absurda, I grant you, it would never be that extreme.
But in much less extreme cases it might very well be --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Like this one?(Laughter)

turn.speaker: james_s_veldman
turn.label: Mr. James S. Veldman
turn.text: I hope that this Honorable Court will not so hold.
Unless the Justices have any further questions of me, as I said, I realize my time is expired.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Dirksen.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
My name is Lawrence Dirksen, and I represent the respondent, John Vitale.

Your Honors, I believe, to clarify some of the questions that first came out, I can probably fill the Court in a little bit on the history of this case because this is the first time that double jeopardy really has ever become an issue.
This case has been all over and every conceivable argument that could have been made against John Vitale by the State of Illinois has been made.
Originally, they challenged us on jurisdiction.
Just to take a step backwards John Vitale was tried on the minor traffic violation.
His uncle represented him on that matter.
He was tried in the suburban court not too far outside of Chicago.
From the conversation I had with his uncle, there was a full trial.
Not only did the witnesses testify against John Vitale, John Vitale testified himself, which is neither here nor there.
But if I had been representing him, I certainly would not have allowed him to take the stand, but he did testify, so it was a full trial.
As I see this case, I have absolutely no argument -- in fact, I entirely agree with Judge Dooley's opinion.
But really what we would be talking about here would be multiple trials if the state would prevail on this final argument because as I say, they had gone from jurisdiction originally.
That didn't work.
They said we can do one thing in the traffic court and we can do something else in the juvenile.
Well, John Vitale is no longer a juvenile, but in those days they thought that they could prosecute him on traffic here and perhaps on the manslaughter over in the juvenile court.
The fact of the matter is that they couldn't do it as an adult.
I raised that question in the Circuit Court, I raise it in the Appellate Court, and I asked the state in front of the Illinois Supreme Court.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You raised that on state grounds?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Your Honor, my original motion was to dismiss the petition for adjudication of delinquency and it was based on statutory and/or constitutional grounds of double jeopardy which had compulsory joinder statutes --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Federal double jeopardy?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Federal or state?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: It was a joint motion, yes.
I won both ways.
The Circuit Court ruled on the compulsory joinder statutes that the matter should have been joined in one trial, one proceeding.
The Appellate Court said the same thing and they further reiterated that --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Could I ask you a question about the argument in the Illinois Appellate Court.
I gather you did represent --

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, I represented him since the juvenile court.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Did the state argue that even on the assumption that the offenses are identical, one being included within the other, nevertheless the Illinois state compulsory joinder statute is not applicable because it doesn't apply to juvenile proceedings or doesn't apply to traffic offenses or something of that character?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: No, I think it was very clear, there was never a question that it did not apply to juveniles.
The state argued that but the court --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The state argued that it did not apply then?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And so is it possible that what the Supreme Court of Illinois was saying is, well, we have identical offenses here, we don't have to decide whether the state compulsory joinder statute applies because in any event when you've got the same offenses you've got the protection under the federal Constitution.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: I believe that is correct, Your Honor.

A juvenile issue was entirely dismissed because I think we all recognize, and everybody did in the courts, the nine judges from the State of Illinois thus far, that juveniles have all the same rights as adults and that is what I was saying when I back-tracked, the state abandoned that argument.
They said, okay, forget about the juvenile question.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: How are we to understand the remand and the answer that the court gave?
Did they say they decided the case solely on double jeopardy grounds?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: I didn't read it that way, Your Honor.
I read it the way Mr. Justice Stevens said.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what did they say?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: They said that Appellate Court held under the compulsory joinder statute that the state --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know, but what did the state say in answer to our remand?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Oh, they sent us back to you and said solely on federal constitutional grounds.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, are we supposed to go behind that or not?
The said solely on --

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Well, Mr. Justice Dooley who wrote the opinion died.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, they are clearly given, given identity of offenses which they found, then as a matter of federal constitutional law there is double jeopardy.
That is solely constitutional grounds.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Your Honor, there is no question they are right.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Of course, you agree that we can't examine the basis of the state holding.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: I absolutely do, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is Mr. Justice Dooley, now deceased, the former Jim Dooley, the noted personal injury lawyer?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Yes, he is, Your Honor, and I believe this was the last opinion that he wrote.
Your Honors, I think it is important for the Court to note that there is not much for me to elaborate on on Justice Dooley's opinion.
I simply agree with it.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: If you are right, there isn't anything more to say, is there?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: And if there are no further questions, then I will conclude my argument.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: May I just ask this question.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Certainly.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Is speed a necessary element in a manslaughter conviction?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: It wouldn't necessarily have to be, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: It would not?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: It would not have to be in every case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You could have a drunk driving down the street at four miles an hour, couldn't you or --

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Or you could have a car trying to leave a parking space that backed up at one mile an hour and crushed somebody behind it.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Certainly you would, Your Honor.
I think maybe I should say something about the case because I have know it that long.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Doesn't that suggest that speed is not an element?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: You see, here we are not talking about the amount of speed, we are talking about the fact that he failed to reduce it, the fact that he failed to reduce speed resulted in a collision with a person, and the death of that person resulted in another charge or two other charges being filed against that same man, those charges being involuntary manslaughter.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Suppose you had a mechanic underneath an automobile and one got in it and drove off without looking, he would drive off, how could he reduce it below zero?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, he could reduce it to zero couldn't he?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: He could, Your Honor, and I think --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: From five miles an hour he could reduce it to zero and then he wouldn't have had a collision.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: I say I simply think the state in this case, they simply erred and they are coming before this Court and saying would you please rectify our error because we don't want to set a bad precedent in Illinois.
This wouldn't happen in an adult case.
It would not have happened if the state had kept its eye on things.
After all, this young man was charged on November 20, 1974, with a traffic offense.
He was tried a month later.
They had plenty of time.

The juvenile officer in South Holland necessarily had to go to the juvenile court, which is loaded with states attorneys, get the necessary petitions to file for an adjudication of delinquency, he obviously had those in his -- I mean this is supposition, but he had to have them at least the next day after the trial because we are talking about a trial that John Vitale went through, and now the state is saying we want another trial because he only had a $15 fine.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, you are not saying under no circumstances under federal jeopardy could he be tried for two totally separate offenses, are you?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
I don't have the argument with the offenses, I have the argument with the multiple trials.

There can be separate offenses tried in a single proceeding, but I don't think you can take one act and charge a number of offenses out of that act and then have separate and successive prosecutions except in extremely limited circumstances.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: How about the statement in Ash v. Swinson that you could bring a person to trial for killing six different poker players if he had not been acquitted in the first trial?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Well, I agree completely with the holding in Ash v. Swanson because, as I understand that case, it was simply a question of identity and --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: There was an acquittal in Ash.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: I know, but I mean double jeopardy applies whether there is an acquittal or a conviction.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But it doesn't necessarily mean that you can't try a man for two different offenses.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: In extremely limited circumstances.
If they --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, that is a view that has been expressed by some members of this Court, but never adopted by the Court.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: I realize that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Your case is Brown v. Ohio which was a court opinion.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: If I were you, I would suggest you stay right there.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: I will stay right there.
I said I --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I think what you are really saying is that Mr. Vitale is mighty lucky a young man to have been charged with a traffic offense --

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Your Honor --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- when he ran down and killed two young children in a guarded school patrol crossing.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Your Honor, hard cases make bad law.
I feel very bad.
In fact, I happen to know one of the parents of the children who was killed, a police officer in South Holland.
It is extremely unfortunate, but I cannot, because those are the factual circumstances, take any different position than any other lawyer could as far as my client's rights are concerned.
The state knew what they were supposed to do.
They have certain requirements that are placed on them.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Would you be here, would you be making this argument except for the state statute, the compulsory joinder rule?
Well, let's suppose that there had been no state rule at all and there had been those same prosecutions in the Supreme Court of Illinois who said this was double jeopardy.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Without compulsory joinder statutes?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No compulsory joinder statute.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Would I still be here?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Would you be arguing that the -- would you be supporting the Supreme Court of Illinois' result on --

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Yes, sir, I would.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Because you think it is a matter of federal double jeopardy irregardless of state law, this is not double jeopardy?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: No, I do think it is double jeopardy in --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You think it is double jeopardy.
But you would say that there is a one transaction test, or don't you?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I don't think we need to go that far.
I am very aware of Mr. Justice Brennan's and Mr. Justice Marshall's transaction test.
I don't think we even need go that far.
I agree with them but I don't think we need to go that far because we are not talking about one transaction, we are talking about one act.
There was an act of an accident, that accident resulted in a traffic charge and two deaths.

And as I pointed out in my brief, if you can take that one act, you could create not only the offense of failing to reduce speed to avoid an accident, you could also create involuntary manslaughter, you could create reckless homicide, you could create reckless conduct, reckless driving, failing --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You are asking them for a principle that has never been enunciated by this Court if for one act you can only be charged once.
Certainly, Brown v. Ohio doesn't say that.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: No, I'm not saying that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You at least say you must abandon the offense test.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Your Honor, all I am saying --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You suggest that even if the offenses are different, and even if to prove the one you don't need to prove something that is involved in the other --

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: No, I say you could prosecute those offenses but you have to do it in one trial.
You can't take one after the other.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know you do, but that has not been the rule --

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: No, that is what I started with, Your Honor, in our own compulsory joinder statute.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know, but I want to know, aside from your compulsory joinder statute.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: I still think all charges that arise out of one act, the separate offenses can be tried but they have to be tried together.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What case do you rely on from this Court for that proposition?
Hopefully this one?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You are standing on the Illinois law when you make that argument, aren't you?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Well, our compulsory joinder statute does provide that, so that is a good place to start.
I mean, it --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: It is a good place to finish, too.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It is a good idea to abandon also, because that is a matter of your state law.
That has never been held here as a matter of constitutional double jeopardy law.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Judge, I am not going to --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Or the other hand, Brown v. Ohio was decided by this Court under the double jeopardy provision as applied to the states for the Fourteenth Amendment and that involved lesser included offenses, and I would think that your argument would be based squarely on that case.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Your Honor, I couldn't more agree with you.
I am simply stating my position philosophically, but I do agree with the decision of Justice Dooley.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: State that on the way home on the airplane.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Dirksen, can I ask you, under the failing to reduce speed statute in Illinois, I notice your client was only fined $15.
What was the maximum penalty under that statute?

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Your Honor, it was a Class C misdemeanor, it could have carried up to a $500 fine and 30 days in jail.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Thirty days.

turn.speaker: lawrence_g_dirksen
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence G. Dirksen
turn.text: Yes.
If there are no further questions, I thank the Court.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I hear none, counsel.
Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
